Even though I was myself momentarily tempted to tell you that your question was nonsense, after reading the other answers, and thinking much more carefully (and less egotistically), I have decided instead, that what you’ve asked is actually brilliant. I want to do a couple of things with my entry. First, is to upvote the various answers which correctly point out that what scientists THOUGHT the “elementary particles” were, has changed a number of times since the idea of “elementary particles” was originated long ago. Therefore, it’s only logical that a fresh student, coming upon the many references which still exist from the past, might be confused by how it appears that The Authority has said “This Is THE Elementary Particle,” only to follow that up soon after, by the discovery of a text saying “THE Elementary Particle is made up of This-tons and That-tons and So-ons.” Next, I think we should all stop and look more carefully at the exact word used in the question: ELEMENTARY. That word refers, intentionally or not, to Elements. And we have a very specific definition of what Elements are. They are defined as things like Iron, Oxygen, Gold, and so on. You can find a chart of all the known ones rather easily these days. And so, for any of us who ARE tempted to make fun, and say the question is silly, we should turn our pointing fingers about and realize that in a very real way, the correct answer to the question as asked, is that Elementary Particles, that is Particles which can be identified AS ELEMENTS, are indeed made up of specific protons, electrons and neutrons. Which brings me to the final note, which needs to underlie all the rest of it. That is, the fundamental nature of attempting to think, and to communicate thoughts, using what we generally call LANGUAGE. Language, even when augmented by sound effects and images, is still beset by limitations, which sometimes even accidentally shape what we think of as possible or true. It’s important for anyone who is serious about knowing about the world, to recognize that language will ALWAYS suffer from limitations, and that we need to allow for those limitations in how we search for knowledge, and how we try to express it, and ESPECIALLY how certain we are, that we have IDENTIFIED IT to begin with.
